div.p:
—The gra-
nitic rock on which we rested is one of those where tra-
vellers on the shores of the Orinoco have heard, from
time to time, towards sunrise, subterraneous sounds,
resembling the tones of the organ. The Missionaries
call these stones musical slabs (laxas de musica). “It
is witchcraft (cosa de bruxas),” said our young Indian
pilot, who could speak English. We never ourselves
heard these mysterious sounds, either at Carichana-
Vieja, or in the Upper Orinoco; but, from information
given us by witnesses worthy of belief, the existerce
of the phenomenon, which seems to depend on a certain
state of the atmosphere, cannot be denied. The shelves
of rock are full of very narrow and deep crevices. They
are heated during the day to 48° or 50°. I several
times found their temperature at the surface, during
the night, at 39°, the surrounding atmosphere being
at 28°. It may easily be conceived that the difference
of temperature between the subterranean and the ex-
ternal air attains its maximum about sun-rise, or at that
moment which is at the same time farthest from the
period of the maximum of the heat of the preceding
day. May not these organ-like sounds, which are heard
when a person lays his ear in contact with the stone, be
the effect of a current of air that issues out through
the crevices? Does not the impulse of the air against
the elastic spangles of mica, which intercept the crevices,
contribute to modify the sounds? May we not believe
that the ancient inhabitants of Egypt, in passing in-
cessantly up and down the Nile, had made the same
observation on some rock of the Thebaid; and that the
“music of the rocks” there, led to the jugglery of the
priests in the statue of Memnon? Perhaps, when “the
rosy-fingered Aurora rendered her son, the glorious
Memnon, vocal,’ the voice was that of a man hidden
beneath the pedestal of the statue; but the observation
of the natives of the Orinoco, which we relate, seems
to explain, in a natural manner, what gave rise to the
Egyptian belief of a stone that poured forth sounds at
sunrise. Almost at the same period at which I com-
municated these conjectures to some of the learned men
of Europe, three French travellers, MM. Jomard, Jol-
lois, and Devilliers, were led to analogous ideas. They
heard at sunrise, in a monument of granite, at the centre
of the spot on which stands the palace of Karnak, a
noise resembling that of a string breaking. Now this
comparison is precisely that which the ancients employed
in speaking of the voice of Memnon. The French
travellers thought, like me, that the passage of rarefied
air through the fissures of a sonorous stone might have
suggested to the Egyptian priests the invention of the
juggleries of the Memnonium. — From Humboldt’s
“Personal Narrative,” Translated and Edited by
Thomasina Ross.
